Package it.unipd.dei.webapp.wacar.dao

Class AbstractDAO<T>

java.lang.Object
it.unipd.dei.webapp.wacar.dao.AbstractDAO<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of the output parameter returned by the DAO.
All Implemented Interfaces:
DataAccessObject<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
DeleteCarCircuitSuitabilityDAO, DeleteFavouriteDAO, DeleteOrderDAO, GetCarDAO, GetCarTypesDAO, GetCircuitDAO, GetCircuitTypesDAO, GetOrderByIdAndUserEmailDAO, GetUserByEmailDAO, InsertCarCircuitSuitabilityDAO, InsertCarDAO, InsertCarTypeDAO, InsertCircuitDAO, InsertCircuitTypeDAO, InsertFavouriteDAO, InsertOrderDAO, ListCarByAvailabilityDAO, ListCarCircuitSuitabilityDAO, ListCarDAO, ListCircuitByCarTypeDAO, ListCircuitDAO, ListFavouriteDAO, ListOrdersByEmailDAO, LoadCarImageDAO, LoadCircuitImageDAO, UpdateAccountDAO, UpdateCarDAO, UpdateCircuitDAO, UserLoginDAO, UserRegisterDAO
public abstract class AbstractDAO<T> extends Object implements DataAccessObject<T>
Provides support for the actual implementation of a DAO object.

AbstractDAO is designed to achieve the following goals:

  1. a consistent way of accessing the database and managing exceptions is guaranteed for all of the classes that need to directly interact with the DBMS.
  2. independence from any particular DBMS is achieved, meaning that the DBMS-dependent code is as isolated as possible and that upper layers can transparently change the underlying DBMS, without the need of modifying their code.

With respect to the first goal, AbstractDAO provides a basic infrastructure which manages the connection, the commitment of transactions (or the roll-back), if needed, and any exception that may be thrown while accessing the database.

With respect to the second goal,AbstractDAO is the root of a hierarchy of helper classes, which isolate as much as possible the DBMS-dependent code.

Concrete subclasses have to implement the abstract method doAccess() in order to define the needed logic for accessing the database. This method is, in turn, called by access(), which provides a consistent way of accessing the database and managing exceptions.

Concrete sub-classes may also override access() in order to provide a different management of connection and transaction if they have peculiar needs. Nevertheless, the objective of this class is to ease sub-classes by providing a pre-packed logic for connection and transaction management, that is what access() does.

Since:
1.0
Version:
1.0
Author:
Nicola Ferro (ferro@dei.unipd.it)
